title: Neil Young pledges $100,000 from Vancouver concert to David Suzuki’s Blue Dot environmental movement
text:
The Blue Dot project wants to press the federal and provincial governments of Canada to declare clean water, clean air and clean soil a constitutional right. 
A pair of Canadian icons appeared together Monday in Vancouver, united in their efforts to keep on rocking in a clean world. 
Canadian-born rock star Neil Young joined Vancouver-based environmentalist David Suzuki Monday afternoon in a media event at Rogers Arena, where Young was set to play a concert. 
Young announced he would donate $100,000 from the proceeds of Monday night’s concert to the David Suzuki Foundation’s Blue Dot movement . 
The Blue Dot movement, Suzuki explained Monday, aims to amend Canada’s Charter of Rights and Freedoms to enshrine environmental rights. 
“I’m very happy to welcome Neil here, who has been such a big supporter to this movement,” Suzuki said. 
Many countries around the world already recognize the right to a healthy environment in their constitutions, Suzuki said, but Canada does not. He added that 87 Canadian municipalities — including Vancouver and Victoria — have now endorsed the Blue Dot movement. 
Young, who was in Vancouver last November to perform for the launch of the Blue Dot movement, said: “Dave really has a great idea here ... I strongly believe in this, I think it’s a great idea. I think Canada should have this and show some leadership.” 
When the press conference opened up to questions from reporters, the topic quickly turned to Canada’s Oct. 19 federal election. 
Asked for his thoughts about this month’s election, Young said: “a lot of people are upset about what’s going on in Canada today. I’m not happy about Canada’s endless search for a drop of oil.” 
As a Canadian citizen who lives in the U.S. and travels around the world, Young said he has seen Canada’s image abroad change “immensely” in recent years. 
“It’s been almost a 180,” he said. “Canada used to be a leader.” 
At one time, Young said, Canada was known as “a country with a conscience.” 
Young said: “This leadership, they’re just backwards, they’re not looking towards the future of the world, they’re not looking towards what we have to do — we have to take care of the future of the planet.”
